title: How to Wash a Gore‐Tex Jacket

steps.headline: Check the tag on your jacket for special instructions.
steps.description: Gore-Tex has a few lines of clothing that have unique washing instructions, such as only using cold water or air drying. Look at the tag on the neck of your jacket to see if there are any specific requirements for cleaning your garment. If there are no special instructions listed on the tag, proceed with the rest of the steps for a standard wash.

steps.headline: Empty the pockets and zip all the zippers on your jacket.
steps.description: Reach into each pocket on your jacket and dig out any loose change, scrap pieces of paper, or larger items. Close the front of the jacket by zipping it up all the way. If you have any zippers on the sides or inside, close those as well. If you have any buttons on your jacket, snap them shut. Close any Velcro strips on the sleeves. Most Gore-Tex jackets don’t have any buttons, so don’t worry if you don’t see any. Zipping the zippers, closing the Velcro straps, and snapping the buttons shut will prevent them from wearing out over time.

steps.headline: Place your jacket in a washing machine and add 1 cap of detergent.
steps.description: Open the door to your washing machine and put the jacket inside on its own. Fill the cap of your detergent bottle with the laundry detergent and pour it over the jacket or into the dispenser.Warning: Don’t use any powder detergents, bleach, or fabric softeners. These will erode the DWR on your jacket and you’ll have to reapply it. They may even permanently discolor or destroy your jacket. If you really want to wash your jacket with other items, put it in a washing bag to prevent other items from rubbing against the fibers. If you don’t, the durable water repellent (DWR) could rub off from the friction. If you don’t have a cap, add 1.5 ounces (45 mL) of detergent.

steps.headline: Wash the jacket with warm water on a low spin cycle.
steps.description: Select warm water, not hot. Set the cycle speed to low in order to keep your jacket safe. If you can customize the rinse settings on your washer, set it to rinse the jacket twice in order to get all of the detergent out of the jacket. If you don’t have custom settings on your machine, use the “delicate” or “hand wash” setting with warm water.

steps.headline: Hang the jacket for at least 20 minutes to let it air dry.
steps.description: Once your jacket is done washing, take it out and put it on a clothing hanger. Place the jacket in a well-ventilated area and let it air dry. Wait at least 20 minutes before taking it off of the rack.Warning: Do not tumble dry any garments marked “shakedry” on the tag. This is a special line of Gore-Tex jackets that requires air drying and shaking. This will save energy, as well as make the DWR easier to reactivate. When you wash the jacket, the DWR has to be reactivated with heat if you want the jacket to remain waterproof. You can tumble dry it immediately if the label mentions it, but line drying your jacket ensures that the jacket keeps its shape. It’s a generally safer option if you want your jacket to last. Depending on your specific model, it may be harder to reactive the DWR if you tumble dry the jacket while it’s wet.

steps.headline: Put the jacket in the dryer and run it on a gentle cycle with medium heat.
steps.description: After the jacket has air dried for 20 minutes, place it in the dryer. Set the dryer to a medium or warm setting and turn the dial to “gentle,” “delicate,” or “low.” Run the dryer for 20 minutes. This will remove the remaining moisture and reactivate the DWR (durable water repellent) coating that keeps your jacket waterproof. Don’t worry if the jacket is still a little damp. The remaining moisture will come out during the drying cycle.

steps.headline: Take the jacket out and hang it to keep it from wrinkling.
steps.description: Once you’ve machine-dried the jacket for at least 20 minutes, take it out of the dryer. Put the jacket on a clothes hanger to keep it from wrinkling. The DWR should have been reactivated by the drying process, but if your jacket isn’t repelling water after you’ve washed it, iron or respray the jacket with a can of DWR.

parts.name: Using an Iron or Spray to Reapply the DWR

steps.headline: Set your jacket out on an ironing board if it’s not repelling water.
steps.description: If you discover that your jacket isn’t repelling water like it’s supposed to after you’ve washed and dried it, set the jacket out on an ironing board. Unzip the jacket and spread it out with the inside facing down. Empty all of the water in your iron’s steam tank if it has one. Plug the iron in and let it preheat on the “warm” setting. You cannot use steam to clean your Gore-Tex jacket.

steps.headline: Place a cloth on top of the jacket and iron the exterior of your garment.
steps.description: Put a cotton towel or shirt on top of the jacket. Once your iron is preheated, start ironing your jacket using smooth, circular motions on top of the cloth. Do not apply any pressure to the iron and don’t let the iron sit on a single section of the cloth for more than 2-3 seconds to avoid over-heating the fibers in the jacket. Iron the entirety of the jacket’s exterior and hang it back up. The heat from your iron should be more than enough to reactivate the DWR on your jacket. You don’t have any DWR on the interior side of your jacket, so don’t worry about ironing it. You can if you really want to though—it won’t harm the jacket. Don’t forget to flip your sleeves over to get both sides!

steps.headline: Spray the jacket with a can of DWR if it still isn’t repelling water.
steps.description: If you find out that the jacket still isn’t repelling water like it should be, order a can of DWR from Gore-Tex or buy some online from another retailer. Zip your jacket up and hang it on a hanger. Hold the can 12–18 in (30–46 cm) away from the jacket and spray the entirety of your jacket. Let it air dry for 1 hour to give the DWR time to settle.Tip: Some building supply stores carry DWR. It’s occasionally marketed as “waterproofing treatment” or “water repellent.” Make sure it’s designed for clothing though by reading the label carefully. Make sure that you spray both sides and get under the arms. If your jacket stopped repelling water after drying and ironing it, then the friction from the wash cycle removed the DWR. In the future, use a lower spin cycle or soak it in hot water with the detergent instead.

text: Using a Washing Machine Check the tag on your jacket for special instructions. Gore-Tex has a few lines of clothing that have unique washing instructions, such as only using cold water or air drying. Look at the tag on the neck of your jacket to see if there are any specific requirements for cleaning your garment. If there are no special instructions listed on the tag, proceed with the rest of the steps for a standard wash. Empty the pockets and zip all the zippers on your jacket. Reach into each pocket on your jacket and dig out any loose change, scrap pieces of paper, or larger items. Close the front of the jacket by zipping it up all the way. If you have any zippers on the sides or inside, close those as well. If you have any buttons on your jacket, snap them shut. Close any Velcro strips on the sleeves. Most Gore-Tex jackets don’t have any buttons, so don’t worry if you don’t see any. Zipping the zippers, closing the Velcro straps, and snapping the buttons shut will prevent them from wearing out over time. Place your jacket in a washing machine and add 1 cap of detergent. Open the door to your washing machine and put the jacket inside on its own. Fill the cap of your detergent bottle with the laundry detergent and pour it over the jacket or into the dispenser.Warning: Don’t use any powder detergents, bleach, or fabric softeners. These will erode the DWR on your jacket and you’ll have to reapply it. They may even permanently discolor or destroy your jacket. If you really want to wash your jacket with other items, put it in a washing bag to prevent other items from rubbing against the fibers. If you don’t, the durable water repellent (DWR) could rub off from the friction. If you don’t have a cap, add 1.5 ounces (45 mL) of detergent. Wash the jacket with warm water on a low spin cycle. Select warm water, not hot. Set the cycle speed to low in order to keep your jacket safe. If you can customize the rinse settings on your washer, set it to rinse the jacket twice in order to get all of the detergent out of the jacket. If you don’t have custom settings on your machine, use the “delicate” or “hand wash” setting with warm water. Drying Your Jacket Hang the jacket for at least 20 minutes to let it air dry. Once your jacket is done washing, take it out and put it on a clothing hanger. Place the jacket in a well-ventilated area and let it air dry. Wait at least 20 minutes before taking it off of the rack.Warning: Do not tumble dry any garments marked “shakedry” on the tag. This is a special line of Gore-Tex jackets that requires air drying and shaking. This will save energy, as well as make the DWR easier to reactivate. When you wash the jacket, the DWR has to be reactivated with heat if you want the jacket to remain waterproof. You can tumble dry it immediately if the label mentions it, but line drying your jacket ensures that the jacket keeps its shape. It’s a generally safer option if you want your jacket to last. Depending on your specific model, it may be harder to reactive the DWR if you tumble dry the jacket while it’s wet. Put the jacket in the dryer and run it on a gentle cycle with medium heat. After the jacket has air dried for 20 minutes, place it in the dryer. Set the dryer to a medium or warm setting and turn the dial to “gentle,” “delicate,” or “low.” Run the dryer for 20 minutes. This will remove the remaining moisture and reactivate the DWR (durable water repellent) coating that keeps your jacket waterproof. Don’t worry if the jacket is still a little damp. The remaining moisture will come out during the drying cycle. Take the jacket out and hang it to keep it from wrinkling. Once you’ve machine-dried the jacket for at least 20 minutes, take it out of the dryer. Put the jacket on a clothes hanger to keep it from wrinkling. The DWR should have been reactivated by the drying process, but if your jacket isn’t repelling water after you’ve washed it, iron or respray the jacket with a can of DWR. Using an Iron or Spray to Reapply the DWR Set your jacket out on an ironing board if it’s not repelling water. If you discover that your jacket isn’t repelling water like it’s supposed to after you’ve washed and dried it, set the jacket out on an ironing board. Unzip the jacket and spread it out with the inside facing down. Empty all of the water in your iron’s steam tank if it has one. Plug the iron in and let it preheat on the “warm” setting. You cannot use steam to clean your Gore-Tex jacket. Place a cloth on top of the jacket and iron the exterior of your garment. Put a cotton towel or shirt on top of the jacket. Once your iron is preheated, start ironing your jacket using smooth, circular motions on top of the cloth. Do not apply any pressure to the iron and don’t let the iron sit on a single section of the cloth for more than 2-3 seconds to avoid over-heating the fibers in the jacket. Iron the entirety of the jacket’s exterior and hang it back up. The heat from your iron should be more than enough to reactivate the DWR on your jacket. You don’t have any DWR on the interior side of your jacket, so don’t worry about ironing it. You can if you really want to though—it won’t harm the jacket. Don’t forget to flip your sleeves over to get both sides! Spray the jacket with a can of DWR if it still isn’t repelling water. If you find out that the jacket still isn’t repelling water like it should be, order a can of DWR from Gore-Tex or buy some online from another retailer. Zip your jacket up and hang it on a hanger. Hold the can 12–18 in (30–46 cm) away from the jacket and spray the entirety of your jacket. Let it air dry for 1 hour to give the DWR time to settle.Tip: Some building supply stores carry DWR. It’s occasionally marketed as “waterproofing treatment” or “water repellent.” Make sure it’s designed for clothing though by reading the label carefully. Make sure that you spray both sides and get under the arms. If your jacket stopped repelling water after drying and ironing it, then the friction from the wash cycle removed the DWR. In the future, use a lower spin cycle or soak it in hot water with the detergent instead.
sentences: Using a Washing Machine Check the tag on your jacket for special instructions.
Gore-Tex has a few lines of clothing that have unique washing instructions, such as only using cold water or air drying.
Look at the tag on the neck of your jacket to see if there are any specific requirements for cleaning your garment.
If there are no special instructions listed on the tag, proceed with the rest of the steps for a standard wash.
Empty the pockets and zip all the zippers on your jacket.
Reach into each pocket on your jacket and dig out any loose change, scrap pieces of paper, or larger items.
Close the front of the jacket by zipping it up all the way.
If you have any zippers on the sides or inside, close those as well.
If you have any buttons on your jacket, snap them shut.
Close any Velcro strips on the sleeves.
Most Gore-Tex jackets don’t have any buttons, so don’t worry if you don’t see any.
Zipping the zippers, closing the Velcro straps, and snapping the buttons shut will prevent them from wearing out over time.
Place your jacket in a washing machine and add 1 cap of detergent.
Open the door to your washing machine and put the jacket inside on its own.
Fill the cap of your detergent bottle with the laundry detergent and pour it over the jacket or into the dispenser.Warning: Don’t use any powder detergents, bleach, or fabric softeners.
These will erode the DWR on your jacket and you’ll have to reapply it.
They may even permanently discolor or destroy your jacket.
If you really want to wash your jacket with other items, put it in a washing bag to prevent other items from rubbing against the fibers.
If you don’t, the durable water repellent (DWR) could rub off from the friction.
If you don’t have a cap, add 1.5 ounces (45 mL) of detergent.
Wash the jacket with warm water on a low spin cycle.
Select warm water, not hot.
Set the cycle speed to low in order to keep your jacket safe.
If you can customize the rinse settings on your washer, set it to rinse the jacket twice in order to get all of the detergent out of the jacket.
If you don’t have custom settings on your machine, use the “delicate” or “hand wash” setting with warm water.
Drying Your Jacket Hang the jacket for at least 20 minutes to let it air dry.
Once your jacket is done washing, take it out and put it on a clothing hanger.
Place the jacket in a well-ventilated area and let it air dry.
Wait at least 20 minutes before taking it off of the rack.Warning: Do not tumble dry any garments marked “shakedry” on the tag.
This is a special line of Gore-Tex jackets that requires air drying and shaking.
This will save energy, as well as make the DWR easier to reactivate.
When you wash the jacket, the DWR has to be reactivated with heat if you want the jacket to remain waterproof.
You can tumble dry it immediately if the label mentions it, but line drying your jacket ensures that the jacket keeps its shape.
It’s a generally safer option if you want your jacket to last.
Depending on your specific model, it may be harder to reactive the DWR if you tumble dry the jacket while it’s wet.
Put the jacket in the dryer and run it on a gentle cycle with medium heat.
After the jacket has air dried for 20 minutes, place it in the dryer.
Set the dryer to a medium or warm setting and turn the dial to “gentle,” “delicate,” or “low.” Run the dryer for 20 minutes.
This will remove the remaining moisture and reactivate the DWR (durable water repellent) coating that keeps your jacket waterproof.
Don’t worry if the jacket is still a little damp.
The remaining moisture will come out during the drying cycle.
Take the jacket out and hang it to keep it from wrinkling.
Once you’ve machine-dried the jacket for at least 20 minutes, take it out of the dryer.
Put the jacket on a clothes hanger to keep it from wrinkling.
The DWR should have been reactivated by the drying process, but if your jacket isn’t repelling water after you’ve washed it, iron or respray the jacket with a can of DWR.
Using an Iron or Spray to Reapply the DWR Set your jacket out on an ironing board if it’s not repelling water.
If you discover that your jacket isn’t repelling water like it’s supposed to after you’ve washed and dried it, set the jacket out on an ironing board.
Unzip the jacket and spread it out with the inside facing down.
Empty all of the water in your iron’s steam tank if it has one.
Plug the iron in and let it preheat on the “warm” setting.
You cannot use steam to clean your Gore-Tex jacket.
Place a cloth on top of the jacket and iron the exterior of your garment.
Put a cotton towel or shirt on top of the jacket.
Once your iron is preheated, start ironing your jacket using smooth, circular motions on top of the cloth.
Do not apply any pressure to the iron and don’t let the iron sit on a single section of the cloth for more than 2-3 seconds to avoid over-heating the fibers in the jacket.
Iron the entirety of the jacket’s exterior and hang it back up.
The heat from your iron should be more than enough to reactivate the DWR on your jacket.
You don’t have any DWR on the interior side of your jacket, so don’t worry about ironing it.
You can if you really want to though—it won’t harm the jacket.
Don’t forget to flip your sleeves over to get both sides!
Spray the jacket with a can of DWR if it still isn’t repelling water.
If you find out that the jacket still isn’t repelling water like it should be, order a can of DWR from Gore-Tex or buy some online from another retailer.
Zip your jacket up and hang it on a hanger.
Hold the can 12–18 in (30–46 cm) away from the jacket and spray the entirety of your jacket.
Let it air dry for 1 hour to give the DWR time to settle.Tip: Some building supply stores carry DWR.
It’s occasionally marketed as “waterproofing treatment” or “water repellent.” Make sure it’s designed for clothing though by reading the label carefully.
Make sure that you spray both sides and get under the arms.
If your jacket stopped repelling water after drying and ironing it, then the friction from the wash cycle removed the DWR.
In the future, use a lower spin cycle or soak it in hot water with the detergent instead.
